docs.lead_paragraph: With the number of uninsured Americans rising to new heights, some policy makers and influential health care experts are saying that the best way to give health coverage to more people is to give some people less. Experiments in several states are establishing stripped-down packages of basic benefits intended to be affordable for employers and uninsured workers, including young, middle-class people who have dropped out of the health insurance pool. Some officials say that government health benefits could be extended to more people, too, if the benefit package were narrower.

headline.main: Broader Health Coverage May Depend on Less

docs.abstract: Some policy makers and influential health care experts are saying that best way to give health coverage to more people is to give some people less; experiments in several states are establishing stripped-down packages of basic benefits intended to be affordable for employers and uninsured workers, including young, middle-class people who have dropped out of health insurance pool; some officials say government health benefits could be extended to more people if benefit package were narrower; idea is one of several ways officials, faced with tight budgets and impatient with federal government, are striving to address consequences of 43 million Americans' going without health coverage; basic-coverage idea is being tested in Utah, Oregon and Idaho and by counties in several other states; is also at core of plan that Maryland Gov Robert L Ehrlich Jr will be presenting to state's Legislature this week; map; photo (M)
docs.snippet: With the number of uninsured Americans rising to new heights, some policy makers and influential health care experts are saying that the best way to give health coverage to more people is to give some people less.    Experiments in several states are...

docs.lead_paragraph: On Monday night, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri came back to the Starlite Ballroom, where it all began. Mr. Gephardt was 47 and strawberry blond when he stood in the ballroom in 1988 and celebrated his victory in the Iowa caucuses before a delirious crowd in his first presidential campaign. He dropped out of that race later, but his victory here propelled him to the leadership of the Democratic Party in the House.

headline.main: Gephardt's Poignant Echo at the Site of His 1988 Victory

docs.abstract: Rep Richard A Gephardt speaks to supporters in Des Moines after finishing fourth in Iowa caucuses; concedes his defeat in Iowa and cancels plans to attend rallies in New Hampshire and South Carolina, instead scheduling flight to his home state of Missouri; aides say he will drop out of race, and Gephardt himself implies as much; says he will support whichever candidate is nominated; his campaign recalled; photo (M)
docs.snippet: On Monday night, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri came back to the Starlite Ballroom, where it all began.     Mr. Gephardt was 47 and strawberry blond when he stood in the ballroom in 1988 and celebrated his victory in the Iowa caucuses...

byline.original: By RACHEL L. SWARNS; Sheryl Gay Stolberg contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush will increase Medicare payments to health maintenance organizations and other private health plans by a record 10.6 percent in an effort to persuade them to enter the Medicare market and increase benefits for the elderly, administration officials say. Federal officials and members of Congress said they hoped the increase, five times as large as the typical annual increase in recent years, would reverse the exodus of private plans from the Medicare program. The administration, trying to enhance competition and efficiency in the Medicare marketplace, wants to triple enrollment in private plans within three years.

headline.main: Private Health Plans to Receive Record Increase From Medicare

docs.abstract: Pres Bush will increase Medicare payments to health maintenance organizations and other private health plans by record 10.6 percent, seeking to reverse exodus of private plans from Medicare programs; goal is to persuade HMO's to enter Medicare market and increase benefits for elderly; increase is five times as large as typical annual increase in recent years; administration is trying to enhance competition and efficiency in Medicare marketplace by tripling enmrollment in private plans within three years; many insurance executives decided they could no longer do business with program because their Medicare-related costs have been rising 10 percent a year, while Medicare payments have risen only 2 percent annually in recent years; Bush administration predicts that Medicare law enacted last month will encourage people to enroll in HMO's and similar private plans; new law creates prescription drug benefit and gives private health plans larger role in program (M)
docs.snippet: President Bush will increase Medicare payments to health maintenance organizations and other private health plans by a record 10.6 percent in an effort to persuade them to enter the Medicare market and increase benefits for the elderly,...

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush intends to use his State of the Union address on Tuesday to set out a multipart approach to helping Americans deal with rising health care costs, including a possible expansion of tax-free savings accounts for medical expenses, people briefed by the White House said on Monday. Addressing an issue sure to be hotly debated during the presidential campaign, Mr. Bush will rely largely on existing proposals to address health care costs, they said. Those ideas include granting tax credits to help people purchase health insurance, allowing small businesses to band together to purchase health coverage for their employees and moving to limit the liability doctors face from malpractice suits.

headline.main: Bush's Address Will Put Focus on Health Care Proposals

docs.abstract: Pres Bush is expected to use his State of Union address to set out multipart approach to helping Americans deal with rising health care costs, including possible expansion of tax-free savings accounts for medical expenses; will rely largely on existing proposals to address health care costs, including allowing small businesses to band together to purchase health coverage for their employees and moving to limit liability doctors face from malpractice suits; Republicans who have been briefed on themes Bush plans to strike in his address say his health care proposals will be offered under umbrella of broader philosophy of giving people more control over, and more responsibility for, their own financial planning; photo (M)
docs.snippet: President Bush intends to use his State of the Union address on Tuesday to set out a multipart approach to helping Americans deal with rising health care costs, including a possible expansion of tax-free savings accounts for medical expenses, people...

And we are going to turn it around by joining the community of nations. We will go back to the United Nations, and we will turn over a new chapter in America's relationship with the world.

docs.lead_paragraph: Exulting in victory, pumping his fists, embracing his wife and saluting his fellow Vietnam veterans, Senator John Kerry, for a moment, sounded almost penitent. ''I've listened to you, and I've learned a lot,'' he told hundreds of overjoyed workers and die-hard supporters on Monday night. ''And you have made me a better candidate, and I thank you for that.''

headline.main: For Up-and-Down Campaign, Iowans Offer a Big 'Up'

docs.abstract: Sen John Kerry addresses hundreds of overjoyed workers and die-hard supporters at his victory rally in Des Moines, Iowa, after Iowa caucuses; alludes to his terrible 2003, when he squandred daunting lead in polls and withstood months of withering criticism, only to shake up his campaign, overhaul his message and his style of reaching voters and make his last stand in Iowa; his struggle recalled; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Many nonprofit organizations responding to a new survey managed to increase their revenue in 2003 despite the sputtering economy, but those gains were more than offset by higher costs. While 64 percent of the 236 organizations across the country that responded reported more income, 66 percent said they had higher costs for health and liability insurance as well as for wages and salaries and other expenses.

headline.main: Many Charities Raised More Money in '03, but Costs Grew Even Faster, Survey Finds

docs.abstract: Many nonprofit organizations responding to new survey managed to increase their revenue in 2003 despite sputtering economy, but say those gains were more than offset by higher costs; 66 percent report higher costs for health and liability insurance as well as for wages and salaries and other expenses; more than half of respondents report being in 'severe' or 'very severe' financial stress (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Howard Dean does not consider himself a reflective man. He avoids queries about how he has evolved over time, what he learned from a struggle, which moments were most meaningful. He focuses step by step by step. But after two years of near-nonstop campaigning, on the eve of the election of his life, Dr. Dean finds himself marching forward almost on autopilot.

headline.main: After Long Hike, Dean Watches His Step
headline.kicker: THE STRUGGLE FOR IRAQ: THE FORMER GOVERNOR

docs.abstract: Howard Dean has been on presidential campaign trail since fall 2001; has emerged from obscurity to become front-runner for Democratic nomination, but he has been struggling lately to maintain momentum as race has tightened to dead heat among four candidates; has wavered between feisty outsider attack that fueled his rise and unity message he adopted in effort to solidify lead; Iowa caucus will be important test for his campaign; Sen Tom Harkin has urged Dean to lighten up to avoid alienating undecided voters; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The job pays 60 bucks for less than two hours' work, which is why eight ordinary Iowans are willing to come, a week before Christmas, to a dingy strip plaza on the outskirts of Des Moines to answer questions from a man they have never met. The five women and three men, seated around a table in an oppressive little room with fluorescent lights, have only two things in common: they all plan to vote in Iowa's Democratic presidential caucuses, and each one is still trying to figure out which candidate to vote for. ''I'd like to know why you're undecided,'' Ed Reilly says to the group. ''I'd like to know what you're looking for.'' Reilly is Dick Gephardt's pollster. He has a distinguished mane of silver hair and a neatly trimmed beard, and on most days you would find him in the office near Wall Street where he does public-opinion polling for corporate America, dressed in an expensive suit and tie. Today he is wearing jeans and cowboy boots.
docs.abstract: Matt Bai article on political polling and its impact on voters; decades of polling have increased voter sophistication but also their suspicion of polling; public imagines candidate consulting pollster on what to think, how to speak and even how to dress to attract support; Ed Reilly, who conducts polling for Rep Dick Gephardt in lead-up to Democratic primary season, describes focus group as way to get at general undercurrent and find relevant emotions that lie beneath surface of data; polling, as imperfect as it is, is mechanism by which campaigns are made responsive; photo (L)
